title: Nicolas Cage Is in on the Nicolas Cage Jokes
abstract: In his new movie, “The Unbearable Weight of Massive Talent,” the actor plays “himself” in all his meme-ified glory.
des_facet: The Unbearable Weight of Massive Talent (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Nicolas Cage as “Nick Cage” in “The Unbearable Weight of Massive Talent.” “I feel closer to my muse and my instrument now than I ever have,” he said.
multimedia.copyright: Sinna Nasseri for The New York Times

title: Let’s Eat Grandma’s Electro Pop Is Glittery. Its Subjects Are Weighty.
abstract: Jenny Hollingworth and Rosa Walton’s band has always been rooted in their deep friendship. Then the tides changed.

multimedia.caption: “The writing process, the recording process, was all about working through those rifts gradually,” Hollingworth said.
multimedia.copyright: Max Miechowski for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: “The writing process, the recording process, was all about working through those rifts gradually,” Hollingworth said.

title: ‘I Deserve to Be Here’: Riding His First Professional Gig to Broadway
abstract: Jaquel Spivey graduated from college last May. Now he’s making his Broadway debut as the star of Michael R. Jackson’s Pulitzer Prize-winning musical, “A Strange Loop.”

multimedia.caption: Made it to curtain call: Spivey with Lyles, center, and Jackson after the first Broadway preview performance.
multimedia.copyright: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Made it to curtain call: Spivey with Lyles, center, and Jackson after the first Broadway preview performance.

title: She’s the Peggy Guggenheim of SoHo
abstract: Steward of a collection of 20th century art, Laura Mattioli made a future for the Futurists at the Center for Italian Modern Art in Manhattan.

multimedia.caption: Laura Mattioli Rossi, the founder of the Center for Italian Modern Art, at her home in SoHo, Manhattan. Above the fireplace are Cy Twombly’s “Untitled,” two parts, 1976, and ceramics by George Ohr. The artwork at right, seen through a window, is on a neighbor’s wall.
multimedia.copyright: Victor Llorente for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Laura Mattioli Rossi, the founder of the Center for Italian Modern Art, at her home in SoHo, Manhattan. Above the fireplace are Cy Twombly’s “Untitled,” two parts, 1976, and ceramics by George Ohr. The artwork at right, seen through a window, is on a neighbor’s wall.
multimedia.copyright: Victor Llorente for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Laura Mattioli Rossi, the founder of the Center for Italian Modern Art, at her home in SoHo, Manhattan. Above the fireplace are Cy Twombly’s “Untitled,” two parts, 1976, and ceramics by George Ohr. The artwork at right, seen through a window, is on a neighbor’s wall.
multimedia.copyright: Victor Llorente for The New York Times

title: ASAP Rocky Arrested in Connection With Los Angeles Shooting
abstract: The rapper, 33, was detained in connection with a November 2021 incident upon returning from Barbados with his pregnant girlfriend, Rihanna.

multimedia.caption: ASAP Rocky was arrested on a charge of assault with a deadly weapon stemming from a nonfatal 2021 shooting in Los Angeles.
ASAP Rocky was arrested on a charge of assault with a deadly weapon stemming from a nonfatal 2021 shooting in Los Angeles.
ASAP Rocky was arrested on a charge of assault with a deadly weapon stemming from a nonfatal 2021 shooting in Los Angeles.

title: ‘Rust’ Producers Get Maximum Fine in Cinematographer’s Death
abstract: The production company, which included the actor Alec Baldwin, was fined $136,000 and was criticized for showing indifference to “recognized hazards.”

multimedia.caption: Workplace safety regulators for the state of New Mexico cited the producers of the film “Rust” on Wednesday for failures on the set that they said contributed to the death of a cinematographer who was fatally shot.

Workplace safety regulators for the state of New Mexico cited the producers of the film “Rust” on Wednesday for failures on the set that they said contributed to the death of a cinematographer who was fatally shot.

Workplace safety regulators for the state of New Mexico cited the producers of the film “Rust” on Wednesday for failures on the set that they said contributed to the death of a cinematographer who was fatally shot.

title: Lincoln Center Plans a Return to Full-Scale Summer Programming
abstract: A festival, Summer for the City, which includes elements of Mostly Mozart, is part of an effort to attract younger, more diverse audiences.
org_facet: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts

multimedia.caption: A rendering of the Oasis, a large outdoor stage designed by Clint Ramos that will feature live music and dance parties at Lincoln Center this summer.
A rendering of the Oasis, a large outdoor stage designed by Clint Ramos that will feature live music and dance parties at Lincoln Center this summer.
A rendering of the Oasis, a large outdoor stage designed by Clint Ramos that will feature live music and dance parties at Lincoln Center this summer.

title: Mary Weatherford Brings ‘Horror and Beauty’ to Venice
abstract: Inspired by Titian’s “The Flaying of Marsyas,” the midcareer artist is showing a series of shadowy and somber works at Museo di Palazzo Grimani.
org_facet: Palazzo Grimani di Santa Maria Formosa (Venice, Italy, Museum)

multimedia.caption: Mary Weatherford with “The Flaying of Marsyas—Satin and 4500 Triphosphor,” 2021-2022, from her body of new work inspired by a Titian painting, at Museo di Palazzo Grimani in Venice.
multimedia.copyright: Matteo de Mayda for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Mary Weatherford with “The Flaying of Marsyas—Satin and 4500 Triphosphor,” 2021-2022, from her body of new work inspired by a Titian painting, at Museo di Palazzo Grimani in Venice.
multimedia.copyright: Matteo de Mayda for The New York Times

title: Parisian Love Stories for the Age of Talk Less, Message More
abstract: Jacques Audiard made his new film “Paris, 13th District” as a counterpoint to the New Wave movies that shaped his early ideas of love and intimacy.

multimedia.caption: Lucie Zhang, center, had not acted before being cast in “Paris, 13th District.”
Lucie Zhang, center, had not acted before being cast in “Paris, 13th District.”
Lucie Zhang, center, had not acted before being cast in “Paris, 13th District.”

title: ‘Artists Are Migrants’: A Nigerian-Irish Dancer’s Multiplicities
abstract: The Lagos-born, Ireland-raised dancer Mufutau Yusuf comes to the Irish Arts Center with “Owe,” a solo, he says, “about my ancestry, my Yoruba heritage.”

multimedia.caption: Mufutau Yusuf in Dewitt Clinton Park, near the Irish Arts Center in Manattan. His method: “Never stay with one idea, but see how that idea migrates and changes depending on the context.”
multimedia.copyright: Nate Palmer for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Mufutau Yusuf in Dewitt Clinton Park, near the Irish Arts Center in Manattan. His method: “Never stay with one idea, but see how that idea migrates and changes depending on the context.”
multimedia.copyright: Nate Palmer for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Mufutau Yusuf in Dewitt Clinton Park, near the Irish Arts Center in Manattan. His method: “Never stay with one idea, but see how that idea migrates and changes depending on the context.”

title: An Interrupted Conversation: The Flamenco Festival Returns
abstract: Despite an impressive roster, including Manuel Liñán’s “Viva!,” this year’s edition, the 20th, represents a radically streamlined version of the festival.

multimedia.caption: A scene from Manuel Liñán’s “Viva!,” featuring an all-male cast who performs in the elaborate, decorative costumes associated with women bailaoras.
A scene from Manuel Liñán’s “Viva!,” featuring an all-male cast who performs in the elaborate, decorative costumes associated with women bailaoras.
A scene from Manuel Liñán’s “Viva!,” featuring an all-male cast who performs in the elaborate, decorative costumes associated with women bailaoras.

title: ‘Some Like It Hot’ Musical Plans Fall Opening on Broadway
abstract: Christian Borle, J. Harrison Ghee and Adrianna Hicks will star in a stage adaptation of the 1959 film comedy about two musicians on the run.

multimedia.caption: Tony Curtis and Marilyn Monroe in a scene from the movie “Some Like It Hot,” which also starred Jack Lemmon.
Tony Curtis and Marilyn Monroe in a scene from the movie “Some Like It Hot,” which also starred Jack Lemmon.
Tony Curtis and Marilyn Monroe in a scene from the movie “Some Like It Hot,” which also starred Jack Lemmon.

title: Radu Lupu, Pianist Who Awed Listeners, Is Dead at 76
abstract: Preferring the stage (and an office chair) to the recording studio, he enthralled audiences with ruminative performances that evoked the otherworldly.

multimedia.caption: Radu Lupu in performance with the New York Philharmonic in 2011. Deciding what to play “has nothing to do with music I like," he said, “but rather music that likes me.”
multimedia.copyright: Jennifer Taylor for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Radu Lupu in performance with the New York Philharmonic in 2011. Deciding what to play “has nothing to do with music I like," he said, “but rather music that likes me.”

title: Protest and Pleasure: Riffs on Classical Indian Art
abstract: Devotion meets consciousness-raising in the first museum survey of the artist-activist Jaishri Abichandani at Craft Contemporary in Los Angeles.

multimedia.caption: Installation view of “Jaishri Abichandani: Flower-Headed Children” at Craft Contemporary in Los Angeles. The artist often riffs on Hindu and pre-Vedic imagery, depicting her own versions of goddesses and spiritual beings.

Installation view of “Jaishri Abichandani: Flower-Headed Children” at Craft Contemporary in Los Angeles. The artist often riffs on Hindu and pre-Vedic imagery, depicting her own versions of goddesses and spiritual beings.

Installation view of “Jaishri Abichandani: Flower-Headed Children” at Craft Contemporary in Los Angeles. The artist often riffs on Hindu and pre-Vedic imagery, depicting her own versions of goddesses and spiritual beings.

title: Nicholas Angelich, Ocean-Straddling Pianist, Dies at 51
abstract: American-born and Paris-based since he was 13, he performed on both sides of the Atlantic, winning acclaim specializing in Germanic repertory.

multimedia.caption: Nicholas Angelich performing with the Rotterdam Philharmonic Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall in New York in 2015. One critic wrote of an Angelich performance in Boston, “Pianissimos floated effortlessly into the hall.”
multimedia.copyright: Hiroyuki Ito for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Nicholas Angelich performing with the Rotterdam Philharmonic Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall in New York in 2015. One critic wrote of an Angelich performance in Boston, “Pianissimos floated effortlessly into the hall.”

title: What’s in Our Queue? ‘HeidiWorld’ and More
abstract: I’m a critic-at-large on the Culture desk. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.

title: ‘The Bad Guys’ Review: Smirking All the Way to the Bank
abstract: In a heist film-inspired DreamWorks comedy, the Big Bad Wolf goes good, begrudgingly.

multimedia.caption: From left, Shark (voiced by Craig Robinson), Wolf (Sam Rockwell) and Tarantula (Awkwafina) in “The Bad Guys.”
From left, Shark (voiced by Craig Robinson), Wolf (Sam Rockwell) and Tarantula (Awkwafina) in “The Bad Guys.”
From left, Shark (voiced by Craig Robinson), Wolf (Sam Rockwell) and Tarantula (Awkwafina) in “The Bad Guys.”

title: This Novel Recounts a Haunted Sibling Relationship in Epic Verse
abstract: Patrick McCabe’s “Poguemahone” is set mostly in hippie-era London, when an Irish brother and sister struggle against society and their own worst natures.

title: Review: The Limón Dance Company Navigates the Present
abstract: The company, belatedly celebrating its 75th anniversary, presented a program with works by Limón and Doris Humphrey and a premiere by Olivier Tarpaga.

multimedia.caption: Nicholas Ruscica, foreground, and the company in Limón’s “Psalm.”
Nicholas Ruscica, foreground, and the company in Limón’s “Psalm.”
Nicholas Ruscica, foreground, and the company in Limón’s “Psalm.”

title: ‘Cypress Hill: Insane in the Brain’ Review: Influential Rappers, Still Smokin’
abstract: This documentary by Estevan Oriol chronicles the rise of a group that he has been around since its inception.

multimedia.caption: Sen Dog, left, and B-Real in “Cypress Hill: Insane in the Brain.”
Sen Dog, left, and B-Real in “Cypress Hill: Insane in the Brain.”
Sen Dog, left, and B-Real in “Cypress Hill: Insane in the Brain.”

title: Diego Maradona: Soccer’s Brilliant, Tortured Bad Boy
abstract: A new biography by a Spanish journalist who had access to members of Maradona’s inner circle.
des_facet: Maradona: The Boy. The Rebel. The God. (Book)

title: Stephen Colbert Isn’t Shocked the New Mask Ruling Came From Florida
abstract: “You can’t let Florida make health decisions for the entire country!” Colbert said.
des_facet: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
The Daily Show with Trevor Noah (TV Program)

multimedia.caption: Stephen Colbert compared the change in mask policy while passengers were mid-flight to “being told halfway through a dinner party that it’s an orgy.”

title: Ezra Miller, ‘The Flash’ Actor, Arrested on Assault Charge in Hawaii
abstract: The ‘Fantastic Beasts’ star was accused of throwing a chair after being asked to leave a home, causing a woman’s injury.

multimedia.caption: The arrest was the second for the actor Ezra Miller in Hawaii in a month.
The arrest was the second for the actor Ezra Miller in Hawaii in a month.
The arrest was the second for the actor Ezra Miller in Hawaii in a month.

title: ‘How I Learned to Drive’ Review: Many Miles to Go Before a Reckoning
abstract: Mary-Louise Parker and David Morse have returned to Paula Vogel’s 1997 Pulitzer-winning play about sexual abuse for its Broadway debut.

multimedia.caption: David Morse and Mary-Louise Parker in Paula Vogel’s play “How I Learned to Drive,” at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater in Manhattan.
David Morse and Mary-Louise Parker in Paula Vogel’s play “How I Learned to Drive,” at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater in Manhattan.

title: Johnny Depp, at Libel Trial, Denies Ever Striking ‘Any Woman’
abstract: Mr. Depp sued his ex-wife Amber Heard for an op-ed she wrote saying she was a “public figure representing domestic abuse.” Ms. Heard maintains that he abused her repeatedly.

multimedia.caption: Johnny Depp, the actor, testified on Tuesday in the defamation case he has brought against his former wife Amber Heard.
Johnny Depp, the actor, testified on Tuesday in the defamation case he has brought against his former wife Amber Heard.
Johnny Depp, the actor, testified on Tuesday in the defamation case he has brought against his former wife Amber Heard.

title: Jorge Drexler’s Music Connects Genres, Generations and Continents
abstract: After three decades of making albums, the Academy Award-winning songwriter is still blending science and poetry, still reaching out to younger artists and still learning.

multimedia.caption: “Tinta y Tiempo” is Jorge Drexler’s 14th studio album in a 30-year recording career.
multimedia.copyright: Gianfranco Tripodo for The New York Times

title: ‘The Runaways,’ ‘Brigsby Bear’ and More Streaming Gems
abstract: This month’s outside-the-box streaming recommendations include quirky comedies, an uncommonly rich music biopic and genre movies that are a cut above.
des_facet: Steve Jobs: The Man in the Machine (Movie)

abstract: Piketty’s “A Brief History of Equality” looks at centuries of economic improvement and suggests new reforms for modern societies.

title: Father Doesn’t Know Best at New Directors/New Films
abstract: Returning to an in-person event, this year’s adventurous festival is filled with discoveries that use families to explore contemporary life.

multimedia.caption: Mediatrice Kayitesi, left, in Kivu Ruhorahoza’s “Father’s Day,” about generational trauma.

title: Alfie Allen Gets in the Zone with Gospel Music and Pineapples
abstract: Known for portraying the luckless Theon Greyjoy on “Game of Thrones,” the British actor shares the items that are helping him prep for his Broadway debut.

title: The Museum of the American Revolution Receives $50 Million
abstract: The gift, from the estate of its founding chairman, H.F. Lenfest, will nearly double the Philadelphia museum’s endowment.

multimedia.caption: The gift was announced on Tuesday, the fifth anniversary of the museum’s opening and the 247th anniversary of the “shot heard ’round the world” in Concord, Mass.
The gift was announced on Tuesday, the fifth anniversary of the museum’s opening and the 247th anniversary of the “shot heard ’round the world” in Concord, Mass.

title: ‘Better Call Saul’ Season 6, Episode 2: Do the Hustle
abstract: Gus and the cartel chase Nacho, Kim and Jimmy pursue Howard — and everyone is conning someone.

multimedia.caption: Marco and Leonel Salamanca (Luis and Daniel Moncada) are out for blood, just not Nacho’s — or at least not all of it.

title: An Immersive Show Taps ‘an Oracle’ for a Spin on Greek Myth
abstract: Punchdrunk’s “The Burnt City” adds techno and sake to the story of the fall of Troy, but it brought in a scholar of classical theater to get the details right.

multimedia.caption: Emma Cole, center, a historical consultant for “The Burnt City,” with Maxine Doyle and Felix Barrett of Punchdrunk. Cole said Punchdrunk’s innovation had “the exact same spirit” as Greek tragedians.
multimedia.copyright: Jeremie Souteyrat for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Emma Cole, center, a historical consultant for “The Burnt City,” with Maxine Doyle and Felix Barrett of Punchdrunk. Cole said Punchdrunk’s innovation had “the exact same spirit” as Greek tragedians.

title: An Opera Rarity Reclaims Its Spot in the Repertory
abstract: Jaromir Weinberger’s “Schwanda the Bagpiper” has been given a persuasive new production by the Komische Oper in Berlin.

multimedia.caption: Philipp Meierhöfer, left, as the Devil and Daniel Schmutzhard as the title protagonist of “Schwanda the Bagpiper” at the Komische Oper.
Philipp Meierhöfer, left, as the Devil and Daniel Schmutzhard as the title protagonist of “Schwanda the Bagpiper” at the Komische Oper.

title: Jerrod Carmichael Knows How to Wear the Truth
abstract: The comedian’s latest HBO special, which explores family secrets and sexual orientation, is as much a therapy session as a stand-up show.

multimedia.caption: The comedian Jerrod Carmichael talks about the impact of family secrets in his HBO special “Rothaniel.”
The comedian Jerrod Carmichael talks about the impact of family secrets in his HBO special “Rothaniel.”

title: As One Alaskan Museum Closed, a Native Heritage Center Prospered
abstract: Wells Fargo closed its museum in Anchorage and has given much of its collection of Native artifacts to another institution that focuses on the state’s Indigenous cultures.

multimedia.caption: The Alaska Native Heritage Center in Anchorage received a gift of 1,700 objects after Wells Fargo closed its nearby museum.
multimedia.copyright: Brian Adams for The New York Times

title: Letizia Battaglia, Photographer of Mafia Brutality, Dies at 87
abstract: Her images of victims on the streets of Palermo were stamped on the nation’s consciousness as she challenged the grip mobsters had on her native Sicily.

multimedia.caption: Ms. Battaglia at her home in 2017. “I never thought of myself as an artist,” she said, “and I am still astonished to enter into a museum and see my work.”
multimedia.copyright: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Ms. Battaglia at her home in 2017. “I never thought of myself as an artist,” she said, “and I am still astonished to enter into a museum and see my work.”

title: Big Tech Wants to Commodify Your Happiness
abstract: In Claire Stanford’s “Happy for You,” a struggling academic joins an internet company building an algorithm to quantify human joy.

title: There’s More to Art in Venice Than the Biennale
abstract: Galleries and foundations across the lagoon city offer a diverse range of works.

multimedia.caption: The German artist Anselm Kiefer created a series of floor-to-ceiling paintings for the Sala dello Scrutinio in one of Venice’s most iconic landmarks, the Doge’s Palace.
